## [html]{.kulas}

+ original markup language <br>(aka document format)
+ HyperText Markup Language 
+ browsers are html <br>processors (analagous to Pandoc)
+ `<Tags>` communicate to browsers 

![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/61/HTML5_logo_and_wordmark.svg/512px-HTML5_logo_and_wordmark.svg.png){.absolute top="150" right="-30" height="400" width="400"}

## [Markdown]{.kulas}

+ Language (2004; *.md)
+ Readability key feature <br>(not a lot of markup)
+ RMarkdown just one of <br>several implementations

![](img/markers.png){.absolute right="-200" height="400" top="150"}

## [Pandoc]{.kulas} 

+ Software ([free](https://pandoc.org/))
+ Universal document <br>converter `r emo::ji("panda")`
+ Markdown processor


![](https://i.natgeofe.com/k/6f2282df-1c6a-474a-9216-ed97b3dce858/Panda-Bamboo_Panda-Quiz_KIDS_1021.jpg?w=1084.125&h=721.875){.absolute top="150" right="-80" height="400" width="550"}

## [pdf]{.kulas}  

+ file format
+ Adobe released 2008

## [element]{.kulas2}

:::: {layout="[80,20]"}

::: {#first-column}

+ part of an HTML document
+ typically consists of:
:::

::: {#second-column}

  1. opening tag
  2. attribute(s)
  3. content
  4. closing tag
:::

::::

:::: {layout="[50,50]"}

:::{#righthandbit}
:::

::: {#lefthandbit}
+ Start `<>` and end `</>` of element
  + ...as well as everything "inside"
+ Bit that formats content
+ Markdown bypasses tags
